title: Lobby trolls and dodging
body: So I just had a ranked game where we had a lobby troll who demanded to play support, even though he was last pick, someone else called support at second pick, and had already locked in. He then proceeded to tell everyone they were guaranteed to lose, and locked in ghost/TP le blanc, saying he was going to feed. So I dodged queue. I'm punished because someone else was up past his bed time and a bit cranky that he couldn't play the one role he called. Shouldn't there be some kind of "kick from lobby" system, where if the 4 other people vote to kick this guy, it starts the queue again, and he is punished? It's not really fair on those of us who just want to play a game, and don't want a child ruining it for us.

Personally i'm gonna say, what's the point?

Have roles picked beforehand makes no sense in a ranked environment, and would result mostly in two features:
1) boosters all being able to boost more effectively
2) no games starting because there would be a lack of diversity in roles (lets be honest, if your in bronze, you don't want to support.)

Team builder itself needs tweaking, but we don't need a ranked version of team builder, we need a tribunal/stricter punishments on people who are like the OP has mentioned (which happens quite a lot i might add)

EDIT: Also ranked TB is basically 5v5 with randoms and no synergy.

Hey man,

Some interesting points you bring up. I'm not on the team working on this feature so I am definitely not a leading expert on this but here is my opinion on a few of your points

> Ranked isn't a thing where we should be able to choose what lane/role we are in, that's not the design of it, you have to be competitive with a group of random 4 people and work well with them (solo queue)

Why shouldn't a player be able to queue what lane/role they want?
If ranked team builder becomes a thing and we can now queue by role we would still be working with a group of random 4 people. The main thing it removes is the friction caused in team select. Think about it, you could even potentially be given a rating per role (i.e. I could be a Diamond mid laner but a gold jungler)

> Have roles picked beforehand makes no sense in a ranked environment, and would result mostly in two features:
> 1) boosters all being able to boost more effectively
> 2) no games starting because there would be a lack of diversity in roles (lets be honest, if your in bronze, you don't want to support.)

1: I don't agree boosters would be able to boost more effectively. Yes they would get their preferred role, but so does everyone else so their opponent would be better as well. Also I really don't think we shouldn't try to improve the champion selection process just because it may or may not make it easier for a small subsection of our player base.

2: If people had the choice *maybe* right now there would be less supports meaning longer queue times. However I think there are enough support players now AND more people would be incentivised to play support with the shorter queue times. (check out the OP's example, 2 support players in one team!)

You say it doesn't make sense, but don't you think alleviating the current champ select pain would go a long way to improving player behaviour and attitudes going into games?

* No more pick vs call order arguments (its pick order guys =P)
* No more X or feed
* No more I only play X
* No more 2 people double mid/jungle/top/adc because people are fighting for the same role
* No more players ending up on their worst role

Hey JasonWazza,

I can see where you're coming from. Your main point is that toxic players are at fault and not the current champion select process. (i.e. toxic players are the cause). I would love to discuss with you about that point and hopefully change your mind.

TL;DR **Most** of the toxicity our players experience is from other players just like them (neutral/positive). The only difference is due to various reasons they are frustrated before even jumping into the game. (losing streak, bad day at work/school, high stress etc). If we remove friction inflection points (e.g. fighting over roles/champions) then we will lower a lot more negative behaviour then just banning actual toxic players.

I can see this is a topic that you are quite passionate about, I would love to hear you opinions on these two videos.

This talks about why **most** of the toxicity players experience is actually from the 90+% normally neutral/positive players that have are having a bad day. And why just removing the toxic players isn't enough, we also need to find ways to prevent neutral and positive players from snapping because of a combination of bad days + in game friction
http://gdcvault.com/play/1017940/The-Science-Behind-Shaping-Player

This talks about why we made team builder in the first place and the key design issues with our current champion select process.
http://www.gdcvault.com/play/1020389/Enhancing-Sportsmanship-in-Online

> I think an Option to kick someone in lobby if they receive 3/4 votes is a good thing.

There are situations where this is useful, but it's very possible for this to be abused pretty significantly.  If someone picks a champion the rest of the team doesn't like or is higher in pick order with a certain role, it's pretty easy for everyone else to vote-kick him or her.  There is some benefit there, but there's also some potential for the facilitation of heavily negative experiences.

>when players get Muted this accounts for something. I.E your auto report/ban features will take them into consideration.

There are a bunch of reasons to mute people, some of which aren't necessarily involved in toxicity.  I'd also be willing to be that toxic players are far more likely to mute others, not just more likely to be muted.  This could pollute the result, potentially.

What use do you feel a system like this would accomplish?  In theory, the reporting system should be quickly and accurately handling offenses without needing to utilize a highly volatile variable like mutes.

>Duo Q team mates reports should only count as 1.
>^ Meaning this way you don't have a duo of assholes reporting that 1 guy they don't like.
and having it count as 2.

If a duo reports someone that doesn't deserve to be punished, the reports will likely not be considered.  Amalgamating all premade into 1 shouldn't necessarily change any outcomes, but it may actually make it harder to pinpoint egregious offenders.  Imagine if you're a 4-person premade and your random is intentionally feeding/being a jerk.  Personally, I feel like all four people should be able to add their report weight to that person to hopefully result in swifter action.

>Ive read this somewhere before can't remember right now, but someone aid they wished to have an option of NEVER to playing with certain people EVER again.

Theoretically, with how large the community is, this shouldn't be happening a ton.  The main problem with a system like this, in my mind, is that in high levels of play there are very few potential skill matchups. 

A player could very easily block everyone better than him or her at that level and never have to play with anyone better.  For most people this isn't a factor, but it's a question of whether it's sufficiently scalable at high levels of play and still useful for lower level players.

> There needs to be a way of giving more power to those who are not toxic

How would you propose Riot go about accomplishing this?

Personally, I think that a volunteer group could have huge impact if implemented really well.  A great example is JaGeX Game Studios' Player Moderator system; players were hand picked by JaGeX to help with reigning in extreme offenders within the community, and were almost universally respected by the playerbase.

>One way of catching abusing people and trolls is to record there actions.
Like what Disco Heat does, but with the exception of not trying to piss them off.

>Like having a Normal game or ranked, while recording.

It's important to consider scale.  The League of Legends community is ~70 million players strong, and if you were to record every single game it would be a completely unrealistic amount of saved data.  Let's just assume each person plays 2 games a day on average, and that the average 30 minute game recording takes 1 GB of space (depends on the recording platform).  

That's ~14 million games per day, and thus 14 thousand terabytes of mostly junk data being generated daily.  This is purely the data rate, this isn't including the systems that need to be built to handle this massive traffic and parse through the recordings to find offenders.

>So the question becomes: If no one listens to a toxic player are they still toxic?

>Like if you think your gonna be toxic: Mute everyone and stop chatting.

It would be great if it were this simple.  People will be people, unfortunately, and expecting everyone to interact properly without systematic reinforcement simply isn't realistic.  Imagine if there were no laws or rules in our lives; what would people be doing?  Many people would probably continue through daily life as normal because of our own conceptions of morality, but others might deviate.

> This isn't the root cause?
> 
> The root cause is these people are toxic.

That is true but for a significant number of matches the hostile environment in which toxic players become violent starts in Champion Select where players argue about roles and champion picks. If everyone had their roles picked before, it would lessen the chance of a match beginning in hostility. 
It won't have a vast and enormous effect on toxicity but it is one factor that directly spawns toxicity that will be removed from a match and hopefully (permanently) from the  whole game over time.

>Why work on stricter punishments when we can remove the root cause of the issue? (not getting the role you want)

I can't upvote this enough.  There are two main facets that result in a huge bulk of the toxicity, in my opinion: champion select and player consistency.  Allowing players to specifically choose their role helps *both* of these areas, because someone that mains a role is far more likely to be happier and more consistent in their play.  This consistency can even help to make matchmaking more accurate, resulting in fewer wide swing games where one team steamrolls the other.

Punishment is fine, but it's kind of a patch in a lot of scenarios rather than a comprehensive solution.
